title: 108_s2981
content: The Act titled "Conventional Arms Threat Reduction Act of 2004" is cited as the short title. The findings and sense of Congress are outlined in the following sections. The global proliferation of MANPADS, small arms, and tactical missile systems poses a direct threat to national security. Terrorist and insurgent groups using these weapons hinder peace efforts in Iraq and Afghanistan. The Government Accountability Office estimates 500,000 to 750,000 MANPADS worldwide. Many countries with these weapons threaten international peace and security. The Government Accountability Office estimates 500,000 to 750,000 MANPADS worldwide. Many countries possess conventional weapons and tactical missile systems, but lack the means to eliminate or safeguard them. The United States lacks a program to address conventional arms threat reduction in other countries. The Department of State has not used the Nonproliferation and Disarmament Fund to eliminate tactical missile systems since 2002. The Department of State has not used the Nonproliferation and Disarmament Fund for any activity to eliminate tactical missile systems since 2002. Congress believes the US should assist countries in securing or eliminating MANPADS, conventional weapons, and tactical missile systems to combat global terrorism and illicit arms trade. The United States Government should focus on combating the proliferation of MANPADS, small arms, light weapons, and tactical missile systems as part of its nonproliferation strategy, due to the links between global terrorism networks and illicit arms trade. The United States aims to assist other countries in safeguarding or eliminating stocks of MANPADS, conventional weapons, and tactical missile systems that pose a proliferation threat through a global program. The Secretary of State is authorized to implement a global program to secure, remove, or eliminate stocks of MANPADS, conventional weapons, and tactical missile systems that pose a proliferation threat. This program may include activities such as humanitarian demining, destruction of small arms and light weapons, and assistance in safe handling and storage of these weapons. The authorized global program includes activities to secure, remove, or eliminate MANPADS, conventional weapons, and tactical missile systems. This involves programs for elimination or securing of MANPADS, assisting countries in safe handling and storage of these weapons, cooperative programs with international organizations, utilization of funds for elimination or safeguarding, and management of these weapons at locations where US funds have been used for security. The curr_chunk focuses on the utilization of funds for the elimination or safeguarding of MANPADS, conventional weapons, and tactical missile systems, as well as the management of these weapons at locations where US funds have been used for security purposes. It also includes actions to ensure that equipment and funds for security upgrades at storage locations continue to be used for authorized purposes. The Office of Conventional Arms Threat Reduction is established within the Department of State to formulate policy and administer programs for conventional arms threat reduction. Additionally, a report on conventional arms threat reduction is required. The Secretary of State must submit a report on conventional arms threat reduction to congressional committees within 180 days of this Act. The report will detail past Department of State efforts, progress in establishing the Office of Conventional Arms Threat Reduction, and country-specific implementation of a global strategy for eliminating or safeguarding conventional weapons. The report required under this Act must include a country-by-country description of the implementation of a global strategy for eliminating or safeguarding MANPADS, conventional weapons, and tactical missile systems. It should also evaluate the integration of activities under this Act and other US programs to ensure consistency with US policy goals in recipient countries. Additionally, it should describe US programs related to the elimination of tactical missile systems. The report required under this Act must include a description of United States programs related to the elimination of tactical missile systems, in unclassified form with a possible classified annex. SEC. 7. Authorization of Appropriations: $50,000,000 authorized for the President in fiscal year 2005 for activities under this Act, with a limitation of $10,000,000 until the Secretary of State submits the required report. SEC. 8. Definitions. The term "appropriate congressional committees" refers to specific committees in the Senate and House of Representatives. The term "Nonproliferation and Disarmament Fund" refers to a fund established under a specific act. The term "small arms and light weapons" includes various types of firearms and weapons. The curr_chunk describes a variety of firearms and weapons including revolvers, pistols, rifles, submachine guns, assault rifles, machine guns, grenade launchers, antiaircraft guns, antitank guns, missiles, mortars, ammunition, explosives, hand grenades, landmines, and rockets.
